metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: JSON .stringify()
A common use of JSON is to exchange data to/from a web server.
content.html: A common use of JSON is to exchange data to/from a web server.

content.text: When sending data to a web server, the data has to be a string.
content.html: When sending data to a web server, the data has to be a string.

content.text: You can convert any JavaScript datatype into a string with JSON.stringify() .
content.html: You can convert any JavaScript datatype into a string with JSON.stringify().

content.text: Stringify a JavaScript Object
Imagine we have this object in JavaScript:
content.html: Imagine we have this object in JavaScript:

content.code_html: const obj = {name: "John", age: 30, city: "New York"};

content.text: Use the JavaScript function JSON.stringify() to convert it into a string.
content.html: Use the JavaScript function JSON.stringify() to convert it into a string.

content.code_html: const myJSON = JSON.stringify(obj);

content.text: The result will be a string following the JSON notation.
content.html: The result will be a string following the JSON notation.

content.text: myJSON is now a string, and ready to be sent to a server:
content.html: myJSON is now a string, and ready to be sent to a server:

content.code_html:
const obj = {name: "John", age: 30, city: "New York"};
const myJSON = JSON.stringify(obj);

content.text: You will learn how to send JSON to a server in the next chapters.
content.html: You will learn how to send JSON to a server in the next chapters.

content.text: Stringify a JavaScript Array
It is also possible to stringify JavaScript arrays:
content.html: It is also possible to stringify JavaScript arrays:

content.text: Imagine we have this array in JavaScript:
content.html: Imagine we have this array in JavaScript:

content.code_html: const arr = ["John", "Peter", "Sally", "Jane"];

content.text: Use the JavaScript function JSON.stringify() to convert it into a string.
content.html: Use the JavaScript function JSON.stringify() to convert it into a string.

content.code_html: const myJSON = JSON.stringify(arr);

content.text: The result will be a string following the JSON notation.
content.html: The result will be a string following the JSON notation.

content.text: myJSON is now a string, and ready to be sent to a server:
content.html: myJSON is now a string, and ready to be sent to a server:

content.code_html:
const arr = ["John", "Peter", "Sally", "Jane"];
const myJSON = JSON.stringify(arr);

content.text: You will learn how to send a JSON string to a server in the next chapters.
content.html: You will learn how to send a JSON string to a server in the next chapters.

content.text: Storing Data
When storing data, the data has to be a certain format, and regardless of where you choose to store it, text is always one of the legal formats.
content.html: When storing data, the data has to be a certain format, and regardless of where you choose to store it, text is always one of the legal formats.

content.text: JSON makes it possible to store JavaScript objects as text.
content.html: JSON makes it possible to store JavaScript objects as text.

content.code_html:
// Storing data:
const myObj = {name: "John", age: 31, city: "New York"};
const myJSON = JSON.stringify(myObj);
localStorage.setItem("testJSON", myJSON);

// Retrieving data:
let text = localStorage.getItem("testJSON");
let obj = JSON.parse(text);
document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = obj.name;

content.text: All Data Types
JSON.stringify() can not only convert objects and arrays into JSON strings, it can convert any JavaScript value into a string.
content.html: JSON.stringify() can not only convert objects and arrays into JSON strings, it can convert any JavaScript value into a string.

content.code_html:
const num = 123e-5;
const myJSON = JSON.stringify(num);

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let bool = new Boolean(1);
const myJSON = JSON.stringify(bool);

content.code:
let bool = new Boolean(1);
const myJSON = JSON.stringify(bool);

syntax_highlighting.text:
let bool = new Boolean(1);
const myJSON = JSON.stringify(bool);

content.code_html:
let bool = new Boolean(1);
const myJSON = JSON.stringify(bool);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let bool = new Boolean(1);
const myJSON = JSON.stringify(bool);

content.text: Stringify a Date
In JSON, date objects are not allowed. The JSON.stringify() function will convert any Date objects into strings.
content.html: In JSON, date objects are not allowed. The JSON.stringify() function will convert any Date objects into strings.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
const obj = {name: "John", today: new Date(), city : "New York"};
const myJSON = JSON.stringify(obj);

content.code:
const obj = {name: "John", today: new Date(), city : "New York"};
const myJSON = JSON.stringify(obj);

syntax_highlighting.text:
const obj = {name: "John", today: new Date(), city : "New York"};
const myJSON = JSON.stringify(obj);

content.code_html:
const obj = {name: "John", today: new Date(), city : "New York"};
const myJSON = JSON.stringify(obj);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
const obj = {name: "John", today: new Date(), city : "New York"};
const myJSON = JSON.stringify(obj);

content.text: You can convert the string back into a date object at the receiver.
content.html: You can convert the string back into a date object at the receiver.

content.text: Stringify a Function
In JSON, functions are not allowed as object values.
content.html: In JSON, functions are not allowed as object values.

content.text: The JSON.stringify() function will remove any functions from a JavaScript object, both the key and the value:
content.html: The JSON.stringify() function will remove any functions from a JavaScript object, both the key and the value:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
const obj = {name: "John", age: function () {return 30;}, city: "New York"};
const myJSON = JSON.stringify(obj);

content.code:
const obj = {name: "John", age: function () {return 30;}, city: "New York"};
const myJSON = JSON.stringify(obj);

syntax_highlighting.text:
const obj = {name: "John", age: function () {return 30;}, city: "New York"};
const myJSON = JSON.stringify(obj);

content.code_html:
const obj = {name: "John", age: function () {return 30;}, city: "New York"};
const myJSON = JSON.stringify(obj);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
const obj = {name: "John", age: function () {return 30;}, city: "New York"};
const myJSON = JSON.stringify(obj);

content.text: This can be omitted if you convert your functions into strings before running the JSON.stringify() function.
content.html: This can be omitted if you convert your functions into strings before running the JSON.stringify() function.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
const obj = {name: "John", age: function () {return 30;}, city: "New York"};
  obj.age = obj.age.toString();const myJSON = JSON.stringify(obj);

content.code:
const obj = {name: "John", age: function () {return 30;}, city: "New York"};
obj.age = obj.age.toString();const myJSON = JSON.stringify(obj);

syntax_highlighting.text:
const obj = {name: "John", age: function () {return 30;}, city: "New York"};
  obj.age = obj.age.toString();const myJSON = JSON.stringify(obj);

content.code_html:
const obj = {name: "John", age: function () {return 30;}, city: "New York"};
obj.age = obj.age.toString();
const myJSON = JSON.stringify(obj);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
const obj = {name: "John", age: function () {return 30;}, city: "New York"};
  obj.age = obj.age.toString();const myJSON = JSON.stringify(obj);

content.text: If you send functions using JSON, the functions will lose their scope, and the receiver would have to use eval() to convert them back into functions.
content.html: If you send functions using JSON, the functions will lose their scope, and the receiver would have to use eval() to convert them back into functions.
